pullRequest.body:
Defined the universal property for the symmetric algebra of a module over a commutative ring, provided an explicit construction and proved that this satisfies the universal property. Also proved that the multivariate polynomial ring generated by a basis of a module satisfies the universal property of the symmetric algebra of that module.

Co-authored-by: Raphael Douglas Giles <raphaeldouglasgiles@gmail.com>, Zhixuan Dai <22300180006@m.fudan.edu.cn>, Zhenyan Fu <fuzhenyan@mail.dlut.edu.cn>, Yiming Fu <fakegreenall@foxmail.com>, Wang Jingting <wangjt2020@163.com>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

#### Import changes for modified files

| `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.SymmetricAlgebra.MvPolynomial` (new file)|1027|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsSymmetricAlgebra`
`+ IsSymmetricAlgebra.mvPolynomial`

`+ lift_comp`
`+ lift_comp_linearMap`
`+ lift_eq`
`+ lift_iota`
`+ lift_unique`
`+ Î¹`
`++ algHom_ext`
`++ lift`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Thanks!

This looks really good, so apart from some more nitpicks this should be good to merge soon.

Thanks!

This looks really good, so apart from some more nitpicks this should be good to merge soon.

We usually avoid using this kind of universal properties as a *definition* because of universe issue: I haven't checked carefully what Lean is doing here, but certainly you cannot quantify over all types in *any* universe. There are multiple solutions here, but I would say the more typical one would be that there exists an isomorphism to "the" symmetric algebra intertwining the structure maps.

Does that make sense?

Well, the thing that lean is doing here seems to be introducing a new universe level for `A`, which becomes the third(?) universe argument in the function. This does cause some where things to happen while proving things(as we've already encountered in the theorems where some of the universe levels are assumed to be the same).
But I do think that's a nice suggestion (I think the same is probably done in `isTensorProduct`?), and I'll DM @Raph-DG on zulip and see how he thinks of that.
Yes, this is exactly the kind of annoyances I was thinking about.

> ADedecker

Thanks for the comment, this is very helpful. It definitely makes sense that what we have currently could cause some universe issues and we should definitely patch it up somehow. I'm wondering though, why is it that having an isomorphism to "the" symmetric algebra is the typical choice for resolving this kind of issue? Intuitively this doesn't feel as nice as using the universal property more directly, at least to me

The reasoning behind it is that "the" symmetric algebra automatically satisfies the universal property *for any universe* thanks to its concrete construction. The alternative approach would be to have size estimates to argue that the universal property actually extends to any universe, but this is a bit annoying to set up.

I agree that it is mathematically unsatisfying, but the key part is really to make the universal property as easy to use as possible, even if that means making the underlying definition a bit ugly. Does that make sense?

Indeed [IsTensorProduct](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/IsTensorProduct.html#IsTensorProduct) is a good source of inspiration here I think.

Right I see, that makes a lot of sense, thanks for explaining it to me :)

We'll change up the definition to make it more like the IsTensorProduct definition
I guess this doesn't apply anymore?

```suggestion
/-- Algebra homomorphism from the tensor algebra over L to the symmetric algebra over L. -/
abbrev algHom : TensorAlgebra R L ââ[R] SymmetricAlgebra R L := RingQuot.mkAlgHom R (SymRel R L)

lemma algHom_surjective : Function.Surjective (algHom R L) :=
  RingQuot.mkAlgHom_surjective _ _

/-- Canonical inclusion of `L` into the symmetric algebra `ð R L`. -/
def Î¹ : L ââ[R] SymmetricAlgebra R L := (algHom R L).toLinearMap.comp (TensorAlgebra.Î¹ R (M := L))

@[elab_as_elim]
theorem induction {C : SymmetricAlgebra R L â Prop}
    (algebraMap : â r, C (algebraMap R (SymmetricAlgebra R L) r)) (Î¹ : â x, C (Î¹ R L x))
    (mul : â a b, C a â C b â C (a * b)) (add : â a b, C a â C b â C (a + b))
    (a : SymmetricAlgebra R L) : C a := by
  rcases algHom_surjective _ _ a with â¨a, rflâ©
  induction a using TensorAlgebra.induction with
  | algebraMap r => rw [AlgHom.map_algebraMap]; exact algebraMap r
  | Î¹ x => exact Î¹ x
  | mul x y hx hy => rw [map_mul]; exact mul _ _ hx hy
  | add x y hx hy => rw [map_add]; exact add _ _ hx hy

open TensorAlgebra in
instance : CommSemiring (SymmetricAlgebra R L) where
  mul_comm a b := by
    have Î¹_commute (x y : L) : Commute (Î¹ R L x) (Î¹ R L y) := by
      simp [commute_iff_eq, Î¹, â map_mul, mkAlgHom_rel _ (SymRel.mul_comm x y)]
    change Commute a b
    induction b using SymmetricAlgebra.induction with
    | algebraMap r => exact Algebra.commute_algebraMap_right _ _
    | Î¹ x => induction a using SymmetricAlgebra.induction with
      | algebraMap r => exact Algebra.commute_algebraMap_left _ _
      | Î¹ y => exact Î¹_commute _ _
      | mul a b ha hb => exact ha.mul_left hb
      | add a b ha hb => exact ha.add_left hb
    | mul b c hb hc => exact hb.mul_right hc
    | add b c hb hc => exact hb.add_right hc
```
The idea behind this is that, rather than use [TensorAlgebra.induction](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/TensorAlgebra/Basic.html#TensorAlgebra.induction), which involves a bit of boilerplate, we might as well make our own induction lemma first. Does that make sense?

Also, using the [Commute](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Group/Commute/Defs.html#Commute) API makes things generally simpler.

```suggestion
lemma lift_Î¹_apply (a : L) : (lift f) ((Î¹ R L) a) = f a := by
```

```suggestion
lemma lift_comp_Î¹ : (lift f) ââ (Î¹ R L) = f := LinearMap.ext fun x â¦ lift_Î¹_apply f x
```

```suggestion
lemma lift_Î¹ : (lift (Î¹ R L)) = AlgHom.id R (SymmetricAlgebra R L) := by
```

```suggestion
lemma algHom_ext (h : IsSymmetricAlgebra f) {F G : A ââ[R] A'}
    (hFG : (F ââ f) = (G ââ f : L ââ[R] A')) : F = G := by
  suffices F.comp h.equiv.toAlgHom = G.comp h.equiv.toAlgHom by
    rw [DFunLike.ext'_iff] at this â¢
    exact h.equiv.surjective.injective_comp_right this
  refine SymmetricAlgebra.algHom_ext (LinearMap.ext fun x â¦ ?_)
  simpa using congr($hFG x)

variable {g} in
lemma lift_unique {F : A ââ[R] A'} (hF : F ââ f = g) : F = (h.lift g) :=
  h.algHom_ext (by simpa)
```
I think it's more natural this way.

pullRequest.title: feat(LinearAlgebra): Symmetric Algebra
